Award.AwardTitle: Mineral Physics Studies of Elasticity, Phonon, and Rheology at Pressure-Temperature Conditions of the Earth's Deep Interior
Award.AbstractNarration:
The mineralogy of the Earth's lower mantle, which comprises the largest fraction of our planet (>55% by volume), was previously regarded as simple and monotonous. An iron-magnesium silicate with the perovskite structure was thought to be the stable mineral unchanging over the enormous pressure and depth range some 400 to 1,800 miles (660 to 2,900 kilometers) below the Earth's surface. With prior NSF grant support, the PI's team made a surprising discovery: at the conditions of the deep lower mantle, the iron-magnesium silicate decomposes into a pure magnesium silicate and a previously unknown Fe-rich silicate mineral with entirely new properties. The next challenge in the present grant is, therefore, to investigate how the new minerals respond to seismic waves and how they deform under compression. The team will use a battery of novel probes for characterization of these properties in-situ under the high pressures and temperatures generated in their laboratory. The results will provide the key for deciphering the seismological information and gain fundamental understanding of the deep Earth interior.

Focused research on the frontier of the deep lower mantle is proposed. Very recently, the perovskite phase of (Mg,Fe)SiO3 was found to disproportionate to an Fe-free MgSiO3 pv and a new Fe-rich hexagonal silicate (H-phase) at the pressure-temperature (P-T) conditions corresponding to the bottom ~1000 km, representing an important, surprising discovery. In the present proposal, the observation of disproportionation and H phase will be further explored and their exact P-T boundaries and physical properties will be investigated. The newly developed multigrain crystallography technique will be applied to P-V-T-x studies in the multiphase region that perovskite, H-phase, and/or post-perovskite coexist. Synchrotron MÃ¶ssbauer spectroscopy, x-ray emission spectroscopy, and nuclear resonant inelastic x-ray scattering will be used to probe the Fe2+/Fe3+ ratio, spin state, and phonon density of state, respectively, for the H-phase in-situ under high P-T. Radial x-ray diffraction and the newly developed Bragg coherent diffraction imaging method will be developed to study lattice preferred orientation and shape-preferred orientation as possible sources of seismic anisotropy in the D" layer. Results from the present study will contribute to fundamental understanding the seismic complexities of the deep lower mantle.

ProgramReference.Text: STUDIES OF THE EARTH'S DEEP INTERIOR

POR.DRECONTENT:
Using first-principles calculations and direct experiments at deep lower-mantle conditions, we discovered a highly stable, iron peroxide (FeO2) that holds an unprecedentedly large amount of oxygen. The new iron peroxide may be synthesized from the high-pressure phase transition of goethite FeO2H, under the deep lower mantle conditions and release H2. The iron peroxide as FeO2Hx may contain residual hydrogen with x between 0 and 1. 

Although the supply of goethite is limited, we demonstrated that the peroxide can also be synthesized from the reaction of the Fe in the core and H2O. When the continuous supply of water from dehydration of the down-going slab meets the inexhaustible iron at the core-mantle boundary, they will form a reaction zone with a complete sequence from iron peroxide, Fe2O3, Fe3O4, FeO, to metallic iron together with iron hydride which will break down to Fe and H2. Hydrogen in the reaction zone will escape upon further heating and rise to the crust, sustaining the water cycle. Our observations indicate a fundamental change in the mode of hydrogen release from hydrous minerals dehydration in the upper mantle to dehydrogenation in the deep lower mantle, thus differentiating the cycles of water and hydrogen. 

These reactions cause accumulation of the heavy superoxidized iron patches at the core mantle boundary, upward migration of hydrogen, and separation of the oxygen and hydrogen cycles, thus essentially turning the deep lower mantle into a giant hydrogen generator. The rising of hydrogen by itself and through reactions with oxides, carbonates, and sulfides at depth, constitute the major source of hydrogen-bearing volatiles, returning to the Earth’s surface as water, hydrocarbon, hydrogen sulfide, etc. 

Ultralow velocity zones (ULVZs) at Earth’s core-mantle boundary (CMB) region have important implications for the chemical composition and thermal structure of our planet, but their origin has long been debated. Using high-pressure experiments and theoretical calculations, we find that FeO2Hx exhibits a high density and Poisson’s ratio as well as extremely low sound velocities consistent with ULVZs. Unlike other ULVZ candidates, FeO2Hx synthesized from the superoxidation of iron by water, would not require an extra transportation mechanism to migrate to the CMB. These dense FeO2Hx-rich domains would be expected to form directly in the CMB region and their properties would provide an explanation for the many enigmatic seismic features which are observed in ULVZs 

Meanwhile, the large-scale, oxygen-rich patches will be a metastable oxygen reservoir at the highly reducing core-mantle boundary.  Continuous accumulation to a critical mass will trigger runaway oxygen outbursts and eruptions which provide the extra energy for chemically driven mantle convection in addition to the normal thermal convections. The episodic events of geodynamics may be manifested on the Earth’s surface as the supercontinent cycles, rifting and collision tectonics, and large-scale flood basalt volcanism. The oxygen eruptions may provide a single, unified theory of colossal global environmental changes, including the great oxidation event, banded-iron formation, snowball Earth, and mass extinctions during the 4.6 billion years history of the Earth.
